text: The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz concerning Judah and Jerusalem, which he saw during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, heavens, and hear, earth;
For the Lord has spoken:
“Sons I have raised and brought up,
But they have revolted against Me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An ox knows its owner,
And a donkey its master’s manger,
But Israel does not know,
My people do not understand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, sinful nation,
People weighed down with guilt,
Offspring of evildoers,
Sons who act corruptly!
They have abandoned the Lord,
They have despised the Holy One of Israel,
They have turned away from Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where will you be stricken again,
As you continue in your rebellion?
The entire head is sick
And the entire heart is faint.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the sole of the foot even to the head
There is nothing healthy in it,
Only bruises, slashes, and raw wounds;
Not pressed out nor bandaged,
Nor softened with oil.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The daughter of Zion is left like a shelter in a vineyard,
Like a watchman’s hut in a cucumber field, like a city under watch.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the Lord of armies
Had not left us a few survivors,
We would be like Sodom,
We would be like Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear the word of the Lord,
You rulers of Sodom;
Listen to the instruction of our God,
You people of Gomorrah!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What are your many sacrifices to Me?”
Says the Lord.
“I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams
And the fat of fattened cattle;
And I take no pleasure in the blood of bulls, lambs, or goats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you come to appear before Me,
Who requires of you this trampling of My courtyards?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not go on bringing your worthless offerings,
Incense is an abomination to Me.
New moon and Sabbath, the proclamation of an assembly—
I cannot endure wrongdoing and the festive assembly.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So when you spread out your hands in prayer,
I will hide My eyes from you;
Yes, even though you offer many prayers,
I will not be listening.
Your hands are covered with blood.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Learn to do good;
Seek justice,
Rebuke the oppressor,
Obtain justice for the orphan,
Plead for the widow’s case.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come now, and let us debate your case,”
Says the Lord,
“Though your sins are as scarlet,
They shall become as white as snow;
Though they are red like crimson,
They shall be like wool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are willing and obedient,
You will eat the best of the land;
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if you refuse and rebel,
You will be devoured by the sword.”
For the mouth of the Lord has spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the faithful city has become a prostitute,
She who was full of justice!
Righteousness once dwelt in her,
But now murderers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your silver has become waste matter,
Your drink diluted with water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your rulers are rebels
And companions of thieves;
Everyone loves a bribe
And chases after gifts.
They do not obtain justice for the orphan,
Nor does the widow’s case come before them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord God of armies,
The Mighty One of Israel, declares,
“Ah, I will have satisfaction against My adversaries,
And avenge Myself on My enemies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then I will restore your judges as at first,
And your counselors as at the beginning;
After that you will be called the city of righteousness,
A faithful city.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion will be redeemed with justice
And her repentant ones with righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But wrongdoers and sinners together will be broken,
And those who abandon the Lord will come to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You certainly will be ashamed of the oaks which you have desired,
And you will be embarrassed by the gardens which you have chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you will be like an oak whose leaf withers away,
Or like a garden that has no water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The strong man will become like flax fiber,
And his work a spark.
So they shall both burn together
And there will be no one to extinguish them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now it will come about that
In the last days
The mountain of the house of the Lord
Will be established as the chief of the mountains,
And will be raised above the hills;
And all the nations will stream to it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And many peoples will come and say,
“Come, let’s go up to the mountain of the Lord,
To the house of the God of Jacob;
So that He may teach us about His ways,
And that we may walk in His paths.”
For the law will go out from Zion
And the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And He will judge between the nations,
And will mediate for many peoples;
And they will beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning knives.
Nation will not lift up a sword against nation,
And never again will they learn war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, house of Jacob, and let’s walk in the light of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You have abandoned Your people, the house of Jacob,
Because they are filled with influences from the east,
And they are soothsayers like the Philistines.
They also strike bargains with the children of foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their land has also been filled with silver and gold
And there is no end to their treasures;
Their land has also been filled with horses,
And there is no end to their chariots.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So the common person has been humbled
And the person of importance has been brought low,
But do not forgive them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Enter the rocky place and hide in the dust
From the terror of the Lord and from the splendor of His majesty.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the Lord of armies will have a day of reckoning
Against everyone who is arrogant and haughty,
And against everyone who is lifted up,
That he may be brought low.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And it will be against all the cedars of Lebanon that are lofty and lifted up,
Against all the oaks of Bashan,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Against all the lofty mountains,
Against all the hills that are lifted up,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Against every high tower,
Against every fortified wall,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Against all the ships of Tarshish
And against all the delightful ships.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: And the idols will completely vanish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People will go into caves of the rocks
And into holes in the ground
Away from the terror of the Lord
And the splendor of His majesty,
When He arises to terrify the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day people will throw away to the moles and the bats
Their idols of silver and their idols of gold,
Which they made for themselves to worship,
speaker: Narrator

text:
In order to go into the clefts of the rocks and the crannies of the cliffs
Before the terror of the Lord and the splendor of His majesty,
When He arises to terrify the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take no account of man, whose breath of life is in his nostrils;
For why should he be esteemed?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The mighty man and the warrior,
The judge and the prophet,
The diviner and the elder,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The captain of fifty and the esteemed person,
The counselor and the expert artisan,
And the skillful enchanter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will make mere boys their leaders,
And mischievous children will rule over them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the people will be oppressed,
Each one by another, and each one by his neighbor;
The youth will assault the elder,
And the contemptible person will assault the one honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a man lays hold of his brother in his father’s house, saying,
“You have a cloak, you shall be our ruler!
And these ruins will be under your authority,”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will protest on that day, saying,
“I will not be your healer,
For in my house there is neither bread nor cloak;
You should not appoint me ruler of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Jerusalem has stumbled and Judah has fallen,
Because their speech and their actions are against the Lord,
To rebel against His glorious presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The expression of their faces testifies against them,
And they display their sin like Sodom;
They do not even conceal it.
Woe to them!
For they have done evil to themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to the righteous that it will go well for them,
For they will eat the fruit of their actions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to the wicked! It will go badly for him,
For what he deserves will be done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people! Their oppressors treat them violently,
And women rule over them.
My people! Those who guide you lead you astray
And confuse the direction of your paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord arises to contend,
And stands to judge the people.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
What do you mean by crushing My people
And oppressing the face of the poor?”
Declares the Lord God of armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moreover, the Lord said, “Because the daughters of Zion are haughty
And walk with heads held high and seductive eyes,
And go along with mincing steps
And jingle the anklets on their feet,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will afflict the scalp of the daughters of Zion with scabs,
And the Lord will make their foreheads bare.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will take away the beauty of their anklets, headbands, crescent ornaments,
speaker: Narrator

text: dangling earrings, bracelets, veils,
speaker: Narrator

text: headdresses, ankle chains, sashes, perfume boxes, amulets,
speaker: Narrator

text: finger rings, nose rings,
speaker: Narrator

text: festive robes, outer garments, shawls, purses,
speaker: Narrator

text: papyrus garments, undergarments, headbands, and veils.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Your men will fall by the sword
And your mighty ones in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And her gates will lament and mourn,
And she will sit deserted on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven women will take hold of one man on that day, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes, only let us be called by your name; take away our disgrace!”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the earth will be the pride and the beauty of the survivors of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it will come about that the one who is left in Zion and remains behind in Jerusalem will be called holy—everyone who is recorded for life in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and purged the bloodshed of Jerusalem from her midst, by the spirit of judgment and the spirit of burning,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord will create over the entire area of Mount Zion and over her assemblies a cloud by day, and smoke, and the brightness of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory will be a canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there will be a shelter to give shade from the heat by day, and refuge and protection from the storm and the rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me sing now for my beloved
A song of my beloved about His vineyard.
My beloved had a vineyard on a fertile hill.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He dug it all around, cleared it of stones,
And planted it with the choicest vine.
And He built a tower in the middle of it,
And also carved out a wine vat in it;
Then He expected it to produce good grapes,
But it produced only worthless ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And now, you inhabitants of Jerusalem and people of Judah,
Judge between Me and My vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What more was there to do for My vineyard that I have not done in it?
Why, when I expected it to produce good grapes did it produce worthless ones?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will lay it waste;
It will not be pruned nor hoed,
But briars and thorns will come up.
I will also command the clouds not to rain on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the vineyard of the Lord of armies is the house of Israel,
And the people of Judah are His delightful plant.
So He waited for justice, but behold, there was bloodshed;
For righteousness, but behold, a cry for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who attach house to house and join field to field,
Until there is no more room,
And you alone are a landowner in the midst of the land!
speaker: Narrator

text:
In my ears the Lord of armies has sworn, “Many houses shall certainly become desolate,
Even great and fine ones, without occupants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For ten acres of vineyard will yield only one bath of wine,
And a homer of seed will yield only an ephah of grain.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who rise early in the morning so that they may pursue intoxicating drink,
Who stay up late in the evening so that wine may inflame them!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore Sheol has enlarged its throat and opened its mouth beyond measure;
And Jerusalem’s splendor, her multitude, her noise of revelry, and the jubilant within her, descend into it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the common people will be humbled and the person of importance brought low,
The eyes of the haughty also will be brought low.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Lord of armies will be exalted in judgment,
And the holy God will show Himself holy in righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the lambs will graze as in their pasture,
And strangers will eat in the ruins of the wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who drag wrongdoing with the cords of deceit,
And sin as if with cart ropes;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes
And clever in their own sight!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are heroes in drinking wine,
And valiant men in mixing intoxicating drink,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who declare the wicked innocent for a bribe,
And take away the rights of the ones who are in the right!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, as a tongue of fire consumes stubble,
And dry grass collapses in the flame,
So their root will become like rot, and their blossom blow away like dust;
For they have rejected the Law of the Lord of armies,
And discarded the word of the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this reason the anger of the Lord has burned against His people,
And He has stretched out His hand against them and struck them.
And the mountains quaked, and their corpses lay like refuse in the middle of the streets.
Despite all this, His anger is not spent,
But His hand is still stretched out.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
No one in it is tired or stumbles,
No one slumbers or sleeps;
Nor is the undergarment at his waist loosened,
Nor his sandal strap broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its arrows are sharp and all its bows are bent;
The hoofs of its horses seem like flint, and its chariot wheels like a storm wind.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: In the year of King Uzziah’s death I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, lofty and exalted, with the train of His robe filling the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seraphim were standing above Him, each having six wings: with two each covered his face, and with two each covered his feet, and with two each flew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And one called out to another and said,
“Holy, Holy, Holy, is the Lord of armies.
The whole earth is full of His glory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the foundations of the thresholds trembled at the voice of him who called out, while the temple was filling with smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said,
“Woe to me, for I am ruined!
Because I am a man of unclean lips,
And I live among a people of unclean lips;
For my eyes have seen the King, the Lord of armies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the seraphim flew to me with a burning coal in his hand, which he had taken from the altar with tongs.
speaker: Narrator

text: He touched my mouth with it and said, “Behold, this has touched your lips; and your guilt is taken away and atonement is made for your sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for Us?” Then I said, “Here am I. Send me!”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Make the hearts of this people insensitive,
Their ears dull,
And their eyes blind,
So that they will not see with their eyes,
Hear with their ears,
Understand with their hearts,
And return and be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, “Lord, how long?” And He answered,
“Until cities are devastated and without inhabitant,
Houses are without people
And the land is utterly desolate,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has completely removed people,
And there are many forsaken places in the midst of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet there will still be a tenth portion in it,
And it will again be subject to burning,
Like a terebinth or an oak
Whose stump remains when it is cut down.
The holy seed is its stump.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it came about in the days of Ahaz, the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin the king of Aram and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to wage war against it, but could not conquer it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was reported to the house of David, saying, “The Arameans have taken a stand by Ephraim,” his heart and the hearts of his people shook as the trees of the forest shake from the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go out now to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shear-jashub, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool, on the road to the fuller’s field,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say to him, ‘Take care and be calm, have no fear and do not be fainthearted because of these two stumps of smoldering logs, on account of the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram and the son of Remaliah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because Aram, with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah, has planned evil against you, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let’s go up against Judah and terrorize it, and take it for ourselves by assault and set up the son of Tabeel as king in the midst of it,”
speaker: Narrator

text: this is what the Lord God says: “It shall not stand nor shall it come to pass.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the head of Aram is Damascus, and the head of Damascus is Rezin (now within another sixty-five years Ephraim will be broken to pieces, so that it is no longer a people),
speaker: Narrator

text: and the head of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If you will not believe, you certainly shall not last.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke again to Ahaz, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ask for a sign for yourself from the Lord your God; make it deep as Sheol or high as heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, nor will I put the Lord to the test!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Listen now, house of David! Is it too trivial a thing for you to try the patience of men, that you will try the patience of my God as well?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Behold, the virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and she will name Him Immanuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will eat curds and honey at the time He knows enough to refuse evil and choose good.
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the boy knows enough to refuse evil and choose good, the land whose two kings you dread will be abandoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will bring on you, on your people, and on your father’s house such days as have not come since the day that Ephraim separated from Judah—the days of the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will whistle for the fly that is in the remotest part of the canals of Egypt and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will all come and settle on the steep ravines, on the ledges of the cliffs, on all the thorn bushes, and on all the watering places.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will shave with a razor, hired from regions beyond the Euphrates River (that is, with the king of Assyria), the head and the hair of the legs; and it will also remove the beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on that day a person may keep alive only a heifer and a pair of sheep;
speaker: Narrator

text: and because of the abundance of the milk produced he will eat curds, for everyone who is left within the land will eat curds and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it will come about on that day, that every place where there used to be a thousand vines, valued at a thousand shekels of silver, will become briars and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will come there with bows and arrows, because all the land will be briars and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for all the hills which used to be cultivated with the plow, you will not go there for fear of briars and thorns; but they will become a place for pasturing oxen and for sheep to trample.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Take for yourself a large tablet and write on it in ordinary letters: Maher-shalal-hash-baz.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will take to Myself faithful witnesses for testimony, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I approached the prophetess, and she conceived and gave birth to a son. Then the Lord said to me, “Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz;
speaker: Narrator

text: for before the boy knows how to cry out ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the spoils of Samaria will be carried away before the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Lord spoke to me further, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Inasmuch as these people have rejected the gently flowing waters of Shiloah
And rejoice in Rezin and the son of Remaliah;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: For so the Lord spoke to me with mighty power and instructed me not to walk in the way of this people, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You are not to say, ‘It is a conspiracy!’
Regarding everything that this people call a conspiracy,
And you are not to fear what they fear or be in dread of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is the Lord of armies whom you are to regard as holy.
And He shall be your fear,
And He shall be your dread.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: Bind up the testimony, seal the Law among my disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will wait for the Lord who is hiding His face from the house of Jacob; I will wait eagerly for Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, I and the children whom the Lord has given me are for signs and wonders in Israel from the Lord of armies, who dwells on Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they say to you, “Consult the mediums and the spiritists who whisper and mutter,” should a people not consult their God? Should they consult the dead in behalf of the living?
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Law and to the testimony! If they do not speak in accordance with this word, it is because they have no dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will pass through the land dejected and hungry, and it will turn out that when they are hungry, they will become enraged and curse their king and their God as they face upward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will look to the earth, and behold, distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish; and they will be driven away into darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there will be no more gloom for her who was in anguish. In earlier times He treated the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali with contempt, but later on He will make it glorious, by the way of the sea, on the other side of the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people who walk in darkness
Will see a great light;
Those who live in a dark land,
The light will shine on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will multiply the nation,
You will increase their joy;
They will rejoice in Your presence
As with the joy of harvest,
As people rejoice when they divide the spoils.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You will break the yoke of their burden and the staff on their shoulders,
The rod of their oppressor, as at the battle of Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For every boot of the marching warrior in the roar of battle,
And cloak rolled in blood, will be for burning, fuel for the fire.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
There will be no end to the increase of His government or of peace
On the throne of David and over his kingdom,
To establish it and to uphold it with justice and righteousness
From then on and forevermore.
The zeal of the Lord of armies will accomplish this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord sends a message against Jacob,
And it falls on Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And all the people know it,
That is, Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria,
Asserting in pride and in arrogance of heart:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The bricks have fallen down,
But we will rebuild with smooth stones;
The sycamores have been cut down,
But we will replace them with cedars.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord raises superior adversaries against them from Rezin
And provokes their enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Arameans from the east and the Philistines from the west;
And they devour Israel with gaping jaws.
In spite of all this, His anger does not turn away,
And His hand is still stretched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet the people do not turn back to Him who struck them,
Nor do they seek the Lord of armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the Lord cuts off head and tail from Israel,
Both palm branch and bulrush in a single day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The head is the elder and esteemed man,
And the prophet who teaches falsehood is the tail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For those who guide this people are leading them astray;
And those who are guided by them are confused.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord does not rejoice over their young men,
Nor does He have compassion on their orphans or their widows;
For every one of them is godless and an evildoer,
And every mouth is speaking foolishness.
In spite of all this, His anger does not turn away,
And His hand is still stretched out.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Manasseh devours Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh,
And together they are against Judah.
In spite of all this, His anger does not turn away
And His hand is still stretched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who enact unjust statutes
And to those who constantly record harmful decisions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
So as to deprive the needy of justice
And rob the poor among My people of their rights,
So that widows may be their spoil
And that they may plunder the orphans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now what will you do in the day of punishment,
And in the devastation which will come from afar?
To whom will you flee for help?
And where will you leave your wealth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nothing remains but to crouch among the captives
Or fall among those killed.
In spite of all this, His anger does not turn away
And His hand is still stretched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to Assyria, the rod of My anger
And the staff in whose hands is My indignation,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I send it against a godless nation
And commission it against the people of My fury
To capture spoils and to seize plunder,
And to trample them down like mud in the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet it does not so intend,
Nor does it plan so in its heart,
But rather it is its purpose to destroy
And to eliminate many nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it says, “Are not my officers all kings?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not Calno like Carchemish,
Or Hamath like Arpad,
Or Samaria like Damascus?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As my hand has reached to the kingdoms of the idols,
Whose carved images were greater than those of Jerusalem and Samaria,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall I not do the same to Jerusalem and her images
Just as I have done to Samaria and her idols?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So it will be that when the Lord has completed all His work on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, He will say, “I will punish the fruit of the arrogant heart of the king of Assyria and the arrogant pride of his eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he has said,
“By the power of my hand and by my wisdom I did this,
Because I have understanding;
And I removed the boundaries of the peoples
And plundered their treasures,
And like a powerful man I brought down their inhabitants,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Is the axe to boast itself over the one who chops with it?
Is the saw to exalt itself over the one who wields it?
That would be like a club wielding those who lift it,
Or like a rod lifting the one who is not wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord, the God of armies, will send a wasting disease among his stout warriors;
And under his glory a fire will be kindled like a burning flame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Light of Israel will become a fire and Israel’s Holy One a flame,
And it will burn and devour his thorns and his briars in a single day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And He will destroy the glory of his forest and of his fruitful garden, both soul and body,
And it will be as when a sick person wastes away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the rest of the trees of his forest will be so small in number
That a child could write them down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on that day the remnant of Israel, and those of the house of Jacob who have escaped, will no longer rely on the one who struck them, but will truly rely on the Lord, the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: A remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: For a complete destruction, one that is determined, the Lord God of armies will execute in the midst of the whole land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore this is what the Lord God of armies says: “My people, you who dwell in Zion, do not fear the Assyrian who strikes you with the rod, and lifts up his staff against you the way Egypt did.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in a very little while My indignation against you will be ended and My anger will be directed toward their destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of armies will wield a whip against him like the defeat of Midian at the rock of Oreb; and His staff will be over the sea, and He will lift it up the way He did in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it will be on that day, that his burden will be removed from your shoulders, and his yoke from your neck; and the yoke will be broken because of fatness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They have gone through the pass, saying,
“Geba will be our encampment for the night.”
Ramah is terrified, and Gibeah of Saul has fled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cry aloud with your voice, daughter of Gallim!
Pay attention, Laishah and wretched Anathoth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Madmenah has fled.
The inhabitants of Gebim have sought refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet today he will halt at Nob;
He shakes his fist at the mountain of the daughter of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He will cut down the thickets of the forest with an iron axe,
And Lebanon will fall by the Mighty One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then a shoot will spring from the stem of Jesse,
And a Branch from his roots will bear fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Spirit of the Lord will rest on Him,
The spirit of wisdom and understanding,
The spirit of counsel and strength,
The spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But with righteousness He will judge the poor,
And decide with fairness for the humble of the earth;
And He will strike the earth with the rod of His mouth,
And with the breath of His lips He will slay the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also righteousness will be the belt around His hips,
And faithfulness the belt around His waist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the wolf will dwell with the lamb,
And the leopard will lie down with the young goat,
And the calf and the young lion and the fattened steer will be together;
And a little boy will lead them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also the cow and the bear will graze,
Their young will lie down together,
And the lion will eat straw like the ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nursing child will play by the hole of the cobra,
And the weaned child will put his hand on the viper’s den.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will not hurt or destroy in all My holy mountain,
For the earth will be full of the knowledge of the Lord
As the waters cover the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then on that day
The nations will resort to the root of Jesse,
Who will stand as a signal flag for the peoples;
And His resting place will be glorious.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then it will happen on that day that the Lord
Will again recover with His hand the second time
The remnant of His people who will remain,
From Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath,
And from the islands of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And He will lift up a flag for the nations
And assemble the banished ones of Israel,
And will gather the dispersed of Judah
From the four corners of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the jealousy of Ephraim will depart,
And those who harass Judah will be eliminated;
Ephraim will not be jealous of Judah,
And Judah will not harass Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
And there will be a highway from Assyria
For the remnant of His people who will be left,
Just as there was for Israel
On the day that they came up out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will say on that day,
“I will give thanks to You, Lord;
For although You were angry with me,
Your anger is turned away,
And You comfort me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God is my salvation,
I will trust and not be afraid;
For the Lord God is my strength and song,
And He has become my salvation.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore you will joyously draw water
From the springs of salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And on that day you will say,
“Give thanks to the Lord, call on His name.
Make known His deeds among the peoples;
Make them remember that His name is exalted.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise the Lord in song, for He has done glorious things;
Let this be known throughout the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rejoice and shout for joy, you inhabitant of Zion,
For great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pronouncement concerning Babylon which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lift up a flag on the bare hill,
Raise your voice to them,
Wave the hand that they may enter the doors of the nobles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have commanded My consecrated ones,
I have also called for My warriors
Who boast in My eminence,
To execute My anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A sound of a roar on the mountains,
Like that of many people!
A sound of an uproar of kingdoms,
Of nations gathered together!
The Lord of armies is mustering the army for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are coming from a distant country,
From the farthest horizons,
The Lord and the weapons of His indignation,
To destroy the whole land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wail, for the day of the Lord is near!
It will come as destruction from the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore all hands will fall limp,
And every human heart will melt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be terrified,
Pains and anguish will take hold of them;
They will writhe like a woman in labor,
They will look at one another in astonishment,
Their faces aflame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, the day of the Lord is coming,
Cruel, with fury and burning anger,
To make the land a desolation;
And He will exterminate its sinners from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the stars of heaven and their constellations
Will not flash their light;
The sun will be dark when it rises
And the moon will not shed its light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will punish the world for its evil
And the wicked for their wrongdoing;
I will also put an end to the audacity of the proud
And humiliate the arrogance of the tyrants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make mortal man scarcer than pure gold
And mankind than the gold of Ophir.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I will make the heavens tremble,
And the earth will be shaken from its place
At the fury of the Lord of armies
In the day of His burning anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And it will be that, like a hunted gazelle,
Or like sheep with no one to gather them,
Each of them will turn to his own people,
And each of them will flee to his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who is found will be thrust through,
And anyone who is captured will fall by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their little ones also will be dashed to pieces
Before their eyes;
Their houses will be plundered
And their wives raped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, I am going to stir up the Medes against them,
Who will not value silver or take pleasure in gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And their bows will mow down the young men,
They will not even have compassion on the fruit of the womb,
Nor will their eye pity children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Babylon, the beauty of kingdoms, the glory of the Chaldeans’ pride,
Will be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Hyenas will howl in their fortified towers
And jackals in their luxurious palaces.
Her fateful time also will soon come,
And her days will not be prolonged.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord has compassion on Jacob and again chooses Israel, and settles them on their own land, then strangers will join them and attach themselves to the house of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: The peoples will take them along and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will make them their own possession in the land of the Lord as male and female servants; and they will take their captors captive and will rule over their oppressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it will be on the day when the Lord gives you rest from your hardship, your turmoil, and from the harsh service in which you have been enslaved,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon, and say,
“How the oppressor has ceased,
And how the onslaught has ceased!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked,
The scepter of rulers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which used to strike the peoples in fury with unceasing strokes,
Which subdued the nations in anger with unrestrained persecution.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The whole earth is at rest and is quiet;
They break forth into shouts of joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the juniper trees rejoice over you, and the cedars of Lebanon, saying,
‘Since you have been laid low, no tree cutter comes up against us.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They will all respond and say to you,
‘Even you have become weak as we,
You have become like us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your pride and the music of your harps
Have been brought down to Sheol;
Maggots are spread out as your bed beneath you
And worms are your covering.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
How you have fallen from heaven,
You star of the morning, son of the dawn!
You have been cut down to the earth,
You who defeated the nations!
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you said in your heart,
‘I will ascend to heaven;
I will raise my throne above the stars of God,
And I will sit on the mount of assembly
In the recesses of the north.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will ascend above the heights of the clouds;
I will make myself like the Most High.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nevertheless you will be brought down to Sheol,
To the recesses of the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who see you will stare at you,
They will closely examine you, saying,
‘Is this the man who made the earth tremble,
Who shook kingdoms,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who made the world like a wilderness
And overthrew its cities,
Who did not allow his prisoners to go home?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the kings of the nations lie in glory,
Each in his own tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you have been hurled out of your tomb
Like a rejected branch,
Clothed with those killed who have been pierced with a sword,
Who go down to the stones of the pit
Like a trampled corpse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will not be united with them in burial,
Because you have ruined your country,
You have killed your people.
May the descendants of evildoers never be mentioned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Prepare a place of slaughter for his sons
Because of the wrongdoing of their fathers.
They must not arise and take possession of the earth,
And fill the surface of the world with cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will rise up against them,” declares the Lord of armies, “and eliminate from Babylon name and survivors, offspring and descendants,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will also make it the property of the hedgehog and swamps of water, and I will sweep it away with the broom of destruction,” declares the Lord of armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of armies has sworn, saying, “Certainly, just as I have intended, so it has happened, and just as I have planned, so it will stand,
speaker: Narrator

text: to break Assyria in My land, and I will trample him on My mountains. Then his yoke will be removed from them, and his burden removed from their shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the plan devised against the entire earth; and this is the hand that is stretched out against all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord of armies has planned, and who can frustrate it? And as for His stretched-out hand, who can turn it back?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that King Ahaz died, this pronouncement came:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do not rejoice, Philistia, all of you,
Because the rod that struck you is broken;
For from the serpent’s root a viper will come out,
And its fruit will be a winged serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are most helpless will eat,
And the poor will lie down in security;
I will kill your root with famine,
And it will kill your survivors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wail, you gate; cry, you city;
Melt away, Philistia, all of you!
For smoke comes from the north,
And there is no straggler in his ranks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What answer will one give the messengers of the nation?
That the Lord has founded Zion,
And the poor of His people will take refuge in it.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the waters of Nimrim are desolate.
Indeed, the grass is withered, the new growth has died,
There is no greenery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the abundance which they have acquired and stored up,
They carry it off over the brook of Arabim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the cry of distress has gone around the territory of Moab,
Its wailing goes as far as Eglaim and its howling to Beer-elim.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Send the tribute lamb to the ruler of the land,
From Sela by way of the wilderness to the mountain of the daughter of Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then, like fluttering birds or scattered nestlings,
The daughters of Moab will be at the crossing places of the Arnon.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Let the outcasts of Moab stay with you;
Be a hiding place to them from the destroyer.”
For the oppressor has come to an end, destruction has ceased,
Oppressors have been removed from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A throne will be established in faithfulness,
And a judge will sit on it in trustworthiness in the tent of David;
Moreover, he will seek justice,
And be prompt in righteousness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore Moab will wail; everyone of Moab will wail.
You will moan for the raisin cakes of Kir-hareseth
As those who are utterly stricken.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Gladness and joy are taken away from the fruitful field;
In the vineyards also there will be no cries of joy or jubilant shouting,
No treader treads out wine in the presses,
For I have made the shouting to cease.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore my inner being sounds like a harp for Moab.
And my heart for Kir-hareseth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So it will come about when Moab presents himself,
When he tires himself upon his high place
And comes to his sanctuary to pray,
That he will not prevail.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the word which the Lord spoke earlier concerning Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the Lord has spoken, saying, “Within three years, as a hired worker would count them, the glory of Moab will become contemptible along with all his great population, and his remnant will be very small and impotent.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pronouncement concerning Damascus:
“Behold, Damascus is about to be removed from being a city
And will become a fallen ruin.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The fortified city will disappear from Ephraim,
And sovereignty from Damascus
And the remnant of Aram;
They will be like the glory of the sons of Israel,”
Declares the Lord of armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now on that day the glory of Jacob will fade,
And the fatness of his flesh will become lean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will be like the reaper gathering the standing grain,
As his arm harvests the ears,
Or it will be like one gleaning ears of grain
In the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet gleanings will be left in it like the shaking of an olive tree,
Two or three olives on the topmost branch,
Four or five on the branches of a fruitful tree,
Declares the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day man will look to his Maker
And his eyes will look to the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he will not look to the altars, the work of his hands,
Nor will he look to that which his fingers have made,
Even the Asherim and incense altars.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For you have forgotten the God of your salvation
And have not remembered the rock of your refuge.
Therefore you plant delightful plants
And set them with vine shoots of a strange god.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the day that you plant it you carefully fence it in,
And in the morning you bring your seed to blossom;
But the harvest will flee
On a day of illness and incurable pain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, the uproar of many peoples
Who roar like the roaring of the seas,
And the rumbling of nations
Who rush on like the rumbling of mighty waters!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations rumble on like the rumbling of many waters,
But He will rebuke them, and they will flee far away,
And be chased like chaff on the mountains before the wind,
Or like whirling dust before a gale.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At evening time, behold, there is terror!
Before morning they are gone.
This will be the fate of those who plunder us
And the lot of those who pillage us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe, land of whirring wings
Which lies beyond the rivers of Cush,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which sends messengers by the sea,
Even in papyrus vessels on the surface of the waters.
Go, swift messengers, to a nation tall and smooth,
To a people feared far and wide,
A powerful and oppressive nation
Whose land the rivers divide.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All you who inhabit the world, and live on earth,
As soon as a flag is raised on the mountains, you will see it,
And as soon as the trumpet is blown, you will hear it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this is what the Lord has told me:
“I will quietly look from My dwelling place
Like dazzling heat in the sunshine,
Like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For before the harvest, as soon as the bud blossoms
And the flower becomes a ripening grape,
He will cut off the shoots with pruning knives,
And remove and tear away the spreading branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be left together for mountain birds of prey,
And for the animals of the earth;
And the birds of prey will spend the summer feeding on them,
And all the animals of the earth will spend harvest time on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At that time a gift of tribute will be brought to the Lord of armies
From a people tall and smooth,
From a people feared far and wide,
A powerful and oppressive nation,
Whose land the rivers divide—
To the place of the name of the Lord of armies, to Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pronouncement concerning Egypt:
Behold, the Lord is riding on a swift cloud and is about to come to Egypt;
The idols of Egypt will tremble at His presence,
And the heart of the Egyptians will melt within them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then the spirit of the Egyptians will be demoralized within them;
And I will confuse their strategy,
So that they will resort to idols and ghosts of the dead,
And to mediums and spiritists.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Furthermore, I will hand the Egyptians over to a cruel master,
And a mighty king will rule over them,” declares the Lord God of armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters from the sea will dry up,
And the river will be parched and dry.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The bulrushes by the Nile, by the edge of the Nile
And all the sown fields by the Nile
Will become dry, be driven away, and be no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the fishermen will grieve,
And all those who cast a line into the Nile will mourn,
And those who spread nets on the waters will dwindle away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moreover, the manufacturers of linen made from combed flax
And the weavers of white cloth will be utterly dejected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the pillars of Egypt will be crushed;
All the hired laborers will be grieved in soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The officials of Zoan are mere fools;
The advice of Pharaoh’s wisest advisers has become stupid.
How can you say to Pharaoh,
“I am a son of the wise, a son of ancient kings”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Well then, where are your wise men?
Please let them tell you,
And let them understand what the Lord of armies
Has planned against Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The officials of Zoan have turned out to be fools,
The officials of Memphis are deluded;
Those who are the cornerstone of her tribes
Have led Egypt astray.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
There will be no work for Egypt
Which its head or tail, its palm branch or bulrush, may do.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Egyptians will become like women, and they will tremble and be in great fear because of the waving of the hand of the Lord of armies, which He is going to wave over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land of Judah will become a cause of shame to Egypt; everyone to whom it is mentioned will be in great fear because of the plan of the Lord of armies which He is making against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day five cities in the land of Egypt will be speaking the language of Canaan and swearing allegiance to the Lord of armies; one will be called the City of Destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the midst of the land of Egypt, and a memorial stone to the Lord beside its border.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it will become a sign and a witness to the Lord of armies in the land of Egypt; for they will cry out to the Lord because of oppressors, and He will send them a Savior and a Champion, and He will save them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord will make Himself known to Egypt, and the Egyptians will know the Lord on that day. They will even worship with sacrifice and offering, and will make a vow to the Lord and perform it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord will strike Egypt, striking but healing; so they will return to the Lord, and He will respond to their pleas and heal them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day there will be a road from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrians will come into Egypt and the Egyptians into Assyria; and the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day Israel will be the third party to Egypt and Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: whom the Lord of armies has blessed, saying, “Blessed is Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel My inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that the commander came to Ashdod, when Sargon the king of Assyria sent him and he fought against Ashdod and captured it,
speaker: Narrator

text: at that time the Lord spoke through Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, “Go and loosen the sackcloth from your hips and take your sandals off your feet.” And he did so, going naked and barefoot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Even as My servant Isaiah has gone naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and symbol against Egypt and Cush,
speaker: Narrator

text: so the king of Assyria will lead away the captives of Egypt and the exiles of Cush, young and old, naked and barefoot with buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will be terrified and ashamed because of Cush their hope and Egypt their pride.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the inhabitants of this coastland will say on that day, ‘Behold, such is our hope, where we fled for help to be saved from the king of Assyria; and how are we ourselves to escape?’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pronouncement concerning the wilderness of the sea:
As windstorms in the Negev come in turns,
It comes from the wilderness, from a terrifying land.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
My mind reels, horror overwhelms me;
The twilight I longed for has been turned into trembling for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They set the table, they spread out the cloth, they eat, they drink;
“Rise up, captains, oil the shields!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this is what the Lord says to me:
“Go, station the lookout, have him report what he sees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he sees a column of chariots, horsemen in pairs,
A train of donkeys, a train of camels,
He is to pay close attention, very close attention.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the lookout called,
“Lord, I stand continually by day on the watchtower,
And I am stationed every night at my guard post.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My downtrodden people, and my afflicted of the threshing floor!
What I have heard from the Lord of armies,
The God of Israel, I make known to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pronouncement concerning Edom:
One keeps calling to me from Seir,
“Watchman, how far gone is the night?
Watchman, how far gone is the night?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchman says,
“Morning comes but also night.
If you would inquire, inquire;
Come back again.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pronouncement about Arabia:
In the thickets of Arabia you must spend the night,
You caravans of Dedanites.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For they have fled from the swords,
From the drawn sword, and from the bent bow,
And from the press of battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what the Lord said to me: “In a year, as a hired worker would count it, all the splendor of Kedar will come to an end;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the remainder of the number of bowmen, the warriors of the sons of Kedar, will be few; for the Lord God of Israel has spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pronouncement concerning the valley of vision:
What is the matter with you now, that you have all gone up to the housetops?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You who were full of noise,
You tumultuous town, you jubilant city;
Your dead were not killed with the sword,
Nor did they die in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All your rulers have fled together,
And have been captured without the bow;
All of you who were found were taken captive together,
Though they had fled far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I say, “Look away from me,
Let me weep bitterly,
Do not try to comfort me concerning the destruction of the daughter of my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord God of armies has a day of panic, subjugation, and confusion
In the valley of vision,
A breaking down of walls
And a crying to the mountain.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then your choicest valleys were full of chariots,
And the horsemen took positions at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And He removed the defense of Judah.
On that day you depended on the weapons of the house of the forest,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then you counted the houses of Jerusalem
And tore down houses to fortify the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you made a reservoir between the two walls
For the waters of the old pool.
But you did not depend on Him who made it,
Nor did you take into consideration Him who planned it long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore on that day the Lord God of armies called you to weeping, to wailing,
To shaving the head, and to wearing sackcloth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead, there is joy and jubilation,
Killing of cattle and slaughtering of sheep,
Eating of meat and drinking of wine:
“Let’s eat and drink, for tomorrow we may die.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Lord of armies revealed Himself to me:
“Certainly this wrongdoing will not be forgiven you
Until you die,” says the Lord God of armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord God of armies says:
“Come, go to this steward,
To Shebna who is in charge of the royal household,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘What right do you have here,
And whom do you have here,
That you have cut out a tomb for yourself here,
You who cut out a tomb on the height,
You who carve a resting place for yourself in the rock?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, the Lord is about to hurl you violently, you strong man.
And He is about to grasp you firmly
speaker: Narrator

text:
And wrap you up tightly like a ball,
To be driven into a vast country;
There you will die,
And there your splendid chariots will be,
You shame of your master’s house!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will depose you from your office,
And I will pull you down from your position.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then it will come about on that day,
That I will summon My servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will clothe him with your tunic
And tie your sash securely around him.
I will hand your authority over to him,
And he will become a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will drive him like a peg in a firm place,
And he will become a throne of glory to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they will hang on him all the glory of his father’s house, the offspring and the descendants, all the least of vessels, from bowls to all the jars.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day,” declares the Lord of armies, “the peg driven into a firm place will give way; it will even break off and fall, and the load that is hanging on it will be cut off, for the Lord has spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pronouncement concerning Tyre:
Wail, you ships of Tarshish,
For Tyre is destroyed, without house or harbor;
It is reported to them from the land of Cyprus.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Be ashamed, Sidon,
For the sea speaks, the stronghold of the sea, saying,
“I have neither been in labor nor given birth,
I have neither brought up young men nor raised virgins.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the report reaches Egypt,
They will be in anguish over the report of Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pass over to Tarshish;
Wail, you inhabitants of the coastland.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is this your jubilant city,
Whose origin is from antiquity,
Whose feet used to bring her to colonize distant places?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has planned this against Tyre, the bestower of crowns,
Whose merchants were princes, whose traders were the honored of the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of armies has planned it, to defile the pride of all beauty,
To despise all the honored of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Overflow your land like the Nile, you daughter of Tarshish,
There is no more restraint.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He has said, “You shall not be jubilant anymore, you crushed virgin daughter of Sidon.
Arise, pass over to Cyprus; even there you will find no rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the land of the Chaldeans—this is the people that did not exist; Assyria allocated it for desert creatures—they erected their siege towers, they stripped its palaces, they made it a ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wail, you ships of Tarshish,
For your stronghold is destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years like the days of one king. At the end of seventy years it will happen to Tyre as in the song of the prostitute:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take your harp, wander around the city,
You forgotten prostitute;
Pluck the strings skillfully, sing many songs,
That you may be remembered.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will come about at the end of seventy years that the Lord will visit Tyre. Then she will go back to her prostitute’s wages and commit prostitution with all the kingdoms on the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her profit and her prostitute’s wages will be sacred to the Lord; it will not be stored up or hoarded, but her profit will become sufficient food and magnificent attire for those who dwell in the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the Lord lays the earth waste, devastates it, twists its surface, and scatters its inhabitants.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people will be like the priest, the servant like his master, the female servant like her mistress, the buyer like the seller, the lender like the borrower, the creditor like the debtor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth will be completely laid waste and completely plundered, for the Lord has spoken this word.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth dries up and crumbles away, the mainland dries out and crumbles away, the exalted of the people of the earth dwindle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth is also defiled by its inhabitants, for they violated laws, altered statutes, and broke the everlasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, a curse devours the earth, and those who live on it suffer for their guilt. Therefore, the inhabitants of the earth decrease in number, and few people are left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The new wine mourns,
The vine decays,
All the joyful-hearted sigh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The joy of tambourines ceases,
The noise of revelers stops,
The joy of the harp ceases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They do not drink wine with song;
Intoxicating drink is bitter to those who drink it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The city of chaos is broken down;
Every house is shut up so that no one may enter.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Desolation is left in the city
And the gate is battered to ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For so it will be in the midst of the earth among the peoples,
As the shaking of an olive tree,
As the gleanings when the grape harvest is over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They raise their voices, they shout for joy;
They cry out from the west concerning the majesty of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore glorify the Lord in the east,
The name of the Lord, the God of Israel,
In the coastlands of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the ends of the earth we hear songs: “Glory to the Righteous One,”
But I say, “I am finished! I am finished! Woe to me!
The treacherous deal treacherously,
And the treacherous deal very treacherously.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terror and pit and snare
Confront you, you inhabitant of the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The earth is broken apart,
The earth is split through,
The earth is shaken violently.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth trembles like a heavy drinker
And sways like a hut,
For its wrongdoing is heavy upon it,
And it will fall, never to rise again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So it will happen on that day,
That the Lord will punish the rebellious angels of heaven on high,
And the kings of the earth on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be gathered together
Like prisoners in the dungeon,
And will be confined in prison;
And after many days they will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the moon will be ashamed and the sun be put to shame,
For the Lord of armies will reign on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem,
And His glory will be before His elders.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For You have turned a city into a heap,
A fortified city into a ruin;
A palace of strangers is no longer a city,
It will never be rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore a strong people will glorify You;
Cities of ruthless nations will revere You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You have been a stronghold for the helpless,
A stronghold for the poor in his distress,
A refuge from the storm, a shade from the heat;
For the breath of the ruthless
Is like a rain storm against a wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like heat in a dry land, You subdue the uproar of foreigners;
Like heat by the shadow of a cloud, the song of the ruthless is silenced.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And on this mountain He will destroy the covering which is over all peoples,
The veil which is stretched over all nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will swallow up death for all time,
And the Lord God will wipe tears away from all faces,
And He will remove the disgrace of His people from all the earth;
For the Lord has spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And it will be said on that day,
“Behold, this is our God for whom we have waited that He might save us.
This is the Lord for whom we have waited;
Let’s rejoice and be glad in His salvation.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the hand of the Lord will rest on this mountain,
And Moab will be trampled down in his place
As straw is trampled down in the water of a manure pile.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he will spread out his hands in the middle of it
As a swimmer spreads out his hands to swim,
But the Lord will lay low his pride together with the trickery of his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The unassailable fortifications of your walls He will bring down,
Lay low, and throw to the ground, to the dust.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Open the gates, that the righteous nation may enter,
The one that remains faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The steadfast of mind You will keep in perfect peace,
Because he trusts in You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust in the Lord forever,
For in God the Lord, we have an everlasting Rock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He has brought low those who dwell on high, the unassailable city;
He lays it low, He lays it low to the ground, He casts it to the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The foot will trample it,
The feet of the poor, the steps of the helpless.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the righteous is smooth;
O Upright One, make the path of the righteous level.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
At night my soul longs for You,
Indeed, my spirit within me seeks You diligently;
For when the earth experiences Your judgments,
The inhabitants of the world learn righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though the wicked person is shown compassion,
He does not learn righteousness;
He deals unjustly in the land of uprightness,
And does not perceive the majesty of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Lord, You will establish peace for us,
Since You have also performed for us all our works.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, our God, other masters besides You have ruled us;
But through You alone we confess Your name.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
We were pregnant, we writhed in labor,
We gave birth, as it seems, only to wind.
We could not accomplish deliverance for the earth,
Nor were inhabitants of the world born.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your dead will live;
Their corpses will rise.
You who lie in the dust, awake and shout for joy,
For your dew is as the dew of the dawn,
And the earth will give birth to the departed spirits.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, my people, enter your rooms
And close your doors behind you;
Hide for a little while
Until indignation runs its course.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For behold, the Lord is about to come out from His place
To punish the inhabitants of the earth for their wrongdoing;
And the earth will reveal her bloodshed
And will no longer cover her slain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day the Lord will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent,
With His fierce and great and mighty sword,
Even Leviathan the twisted serpent;
And He will kill the dragon who lives in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day,
“A vineyard of beauty, sing of it!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I, the Lord, am its keeper;
I water it every moment.
So that no one will damage it,
I guard it night and day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have no wrath.
Should someone give Me briars and thorns in battle,
Then I would step on them, I would burn them completely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or let him rely on My protection,
Let him make peace with Me,
Let him make peace with Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the days to come Jacob will take root,
Israel will blossom and sprout,
And they will fill the whole world with fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like the striking of Him who has struck them, has He struck them?
Or like the slaughter of His slain, have they been slain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You contended with them by banishing them, by driving them away.
With His fierce wind He has expelled them on the day of the east wind.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the fortified city is isolated,
A homestead deserted and abandoned like the desert;
There the calf will graze,
And there it will lie down and feed on its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When its limbs are dry, they are broken off;
Women come and make a fire with them,
For they are not a people of discernment,
Therefore their Maker will not have compassion on them.
And their Creator will not be gracious to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will thresh from the flowing stream of the Euphrates River to the brook of Egypt, and you will be gathered up one by one, you sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will come about also on that day that a great trumpet will be blown, and those who were perishing in the land of Assyria and who were scattered in the land of Egypt will come and worship the Lord on the holy mountain in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to the proud crown of the habitually drunk of Ephraim,
And to the fading flower of its glorious beauty,
Which is at the head of the fertile valley
Of those who are overcome with wine!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, the Lord has a strong and mighty agent;
As a storm of hail, a tempest of destruction,
Like a storm of mighty overflowing waters,
He has thrown it down to the earth with His hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The splendid crown of the habitually drunk of Ephraim is trampled underfoot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the fading flower of its glorious beauty,
Which is at the head of the fertile valley,
Will be like the first-ripe fig prior to the summer,
Which one sees,
And as soon as it is in his hand,
He swallows it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day the Lord of armies will become a beautiful crown
And a glorious wreath to the remnant of His people;
speaker: Narrator

text:
A spirit of justice for him who sits in judgment,
A strength to those who repel the onslaught at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And these also reel with wine and stagger from intoxicating drink:
The priest and the prophet reel with intoxicating drink,
They are confused by wine, they stagger from intoxicating drink;
They reel while having visions,
They stagger when rendering a verdict.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all the tables are full of filthy vomit, without a single clean place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“To whom would He teach knowledge,
And to whom would He interpret the message?
Those just weaned from milk?
Those just taken from the breast?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He says,
‘Order on order, order on order,
Line on line, line on line,
A little here, a little there.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, He will speak to this people
Through stammering lips and a foreign tongue,
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who said to them, “This is the place of quiet, give rest to the weary,”
And, “This is the resting place,” but they would not listen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the word of the Lord to them will be,
“Order on order, order on order,
Line on line, line on line,
A little here, a little there,”
That they may go and stumble backward, be broken, snared, and taken captive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, hear the word of the Lord, you scoffers,
Who rule this people who are in Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you have said, “We have made a covenant with death,
And with Sheol we have made a pact.
The gushing flood will not reach us when it passes by,
Because we have made falsehood our refuge and we have concealed ourselves with deception.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore this is what the Lord God says:
“Behold, I am laying a stone in Zion, a tested stone,
A precious cornerstone for the foundation, firmly placed.
The one who believes in it will not be disturbed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make justice the measuring line
And righteousness the level;
Then hail will sweep away the refuge of lies,
And the waters will overflow the secret place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your covenant with death will be canceled,
And your pact with Sheol will not stand;
When the gushing flood passes through,
Then you will become its trampling ground.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The bed is too short on which to stretch out,
And the blanket is too small to wrap oneself in.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord will rise up as at Mount Perazim,
He will be stirred up as in the Valley of Gibeon,
To do His task, His unusual task,
And to work His work, His extraordinary work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now do not carry on as scoffers,
Or your shackles will be made stronger;
For I have heard from the Lord God of armies
Of decisive destruction on all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen and hear my voice,
Pay attention and hear my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does the farmer plow continually to plant seed?
Does he continually turn and break up his ground?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does he not level its surface
And sow dill and scatter cumin
And plant wheat in rows,
Barley in its place and rye within its area?
speaker: Narrator

text: For his God instructs and teaches him properly.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Grain for bread is crushed,
Indeed, he does not continue to thresh it forever.
Because the wheel of his cart and his horses eventually damage it,
He does not thresh it longer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This also comes from the Lord of armies,
Who has made His counsel wonderful and His wisdom great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe, Ariel, Ariel the city where David once camped!
Add year to year, keep your feasts on schedule.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will camp against you encircling you,
And I will set up siegeworks against you,
And I will raise up battle towers against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will be brought low;
From the earth you will speak,
And from the dust where you are prostrate
Your words will come.
Your voice will also be like that of a spirit from the ground,
And your speech will whisper from the dust.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
From the Lord of armies you will be punished with thunder and earthquake and loud noise,
With whirlwind and tempest and the flame of a consuming fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the multitude of all the nations who wage war against Ariel,
Even all who wage war against her and her stronghold, and who distress her,
Will be like a dream, a vision of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will be as when a hungry person dreams—
And behold, he is eating;
But when he awakens, his hunger is not satisfied,
Or as when a thirsty person dreams—
And behold, he is drinking,
But when he awakens, behold, he is faint
And his thirst is not quenched.
So will the multitude of all the nations be
Who wage war against Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be delayed and horrified,
Blind yourselves and be blind;
They become drunk, but not with wine,
They stagger, but not with intoxicating drink.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: The entire vision will be to you like the words of a sealed book, which, when they give it to the one who is literate, saying, “Please read this,” he will say, “I cannot, because it is sealed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the book will be given to the one who is illiterate, saying, “Please read this.” And he will say, “I cannot read.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord said,
“Because this people approaches Me with their words
And honors Me with their lips,
But their heart is far away from Me,
And their reverence for Me consists of the commandment of men that is taught;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Woe to those who deeply hide their plans from the Lord,
And whose deeds are done in a dark place,
And they say, “Who sees us?” or “Who knows us?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
You turn things around!
Shall the potter be considered as equal with the clay,
That what is made would say to its maker, “He did not make me”;
Or what is formed say to him who formed it, “He has no understanding”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it not yet just a little while
Before Lebanon will be turned into a fertile field,
And the fertile field will be considered as a forest?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day those who are deaf will hear words of a book,
And out of their gloom and darkness the eyes of those who are blind will see.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The afflicted also will increase their joy in the Lord,
And the needy of mankind will rejoice in the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the ruthless will come to an end and the scorner will be finished,
Indeed all who are intent on doing evil will be eliminated,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who cause a person to be indicted by a word,
And set a trap for the arbitrator at the gate,
And defraud the one in the right with meaningless arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore this is what the Lord, who redeemed Abraham, says concerning the house of Jacob:
“Jacob will not be ashamed now, nor will his face turn pale now;
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when he sees his children, the work of My hands, in his midst,
They will sanctify My name;
Indeed, they will sanctify the Holy One of Jacob,
And will stand in awe of the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who err in mind will know the truth,
And those who criticize will accept instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Woe to the rebellious children,” declares the Lord,
“Who execute a plan, but not Mine,
And make an alliance, but not of My Spirit,
In order to add sin to sin;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who proceed down to Egypt
Without consulting Me,
To take refuge in the safety of Pharaoh,
And to seek shelter in the shadow of Egypt!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the safety of Pharaoh will be your shame,
And the shelter in the shadow of Egypt, your humiliation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For their officials are at Zoan
